data.title: This Week in the History of Chemistry
data.text:
This Week

in the

History of Chemistry

JanuaryFebruaryMarchApril MayJuneJulyAugust SeptemberOctoberNovemberDecember

Sources

See also This Month in the History of the Periodic Table (with links to a searchable online map).

July 28-August 17

July 28293031 August 123 45678910 11121314151617

Broken links repaired 31 July 2024.

50-year, 100-year, 150-year, etc. anniversaries appear in bold red.

See also Today in Science History by Ian Ellis.

July 28

James Curtis Booth born 1810: methods for refining gold-silver bullion at US Mint, Philadelphia.

July 29

Heinz Fraenkel-Conrat born 1910: separated viral RNA from protein and showed that RNA was the active agent, turning attention to the role of nucleic acids in heredity. Isidor Isaac Rabi born 1898: atomic and molecular beam spectroscopy; nuclear magnetic properties; Nobel Prize (Physics), 1944 Walter Julius Reppe born 1892: industrial organic chemistry (at BASF); high-pressure reactions of acetylene.

July 30

The "Charles" of Antwerp, Belgium, becomes the "first oil tanker", 1869, carrying oil from the U.S. to Europe in iron tanks below decks.

July 31

August Beer born 1825: Beer-Lambert law relating absorption of light to concentration of absorbing material Paul Delos Boyer born 1918: enzymatic mechanism of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) synthesis; Nobel Prize, 1997.

The first US patent was in industrial chemistry, issued in 1790 to Samuel Hopkins on a process for making potash and pearl ashes (signed by President Washington). [Link to US Patent and Trademark Office.]

Stephanie Kwolek born 1923: invented Kevlar® (US patent 3,819,587); Perkin medal 1997. Primo Levi born 1919: chemically-trained memoirist; Survival in Auschwitz and The Periodic Table; died by suicide (?) in 1987 Sofia Simmonds born 1917: amino acid metabolism of bacteria; Garvan Medal, 1969. Friedrich Wöhler born 1800: synthesis of organic compounds from inorganic materials (oxalic acid and urea); isolated aluminum (Al, element 13) and beryllium (Be, 4); preparation of acetylene (ethyne) from calcium carbide

August 1

Joseph Henry Gilbert born 1817: nitrogen fertilizers Charles Robert Harington born 1897: biochemist; synthesized thyroxine with G. Barger George de Hevesy born 1885: radioisotopes; co-discoverer of hafnium (Hf, element 72); Nobel prize, 1943. Richard Kirwan born 1733: specific heats; defender of phlogiston eventually converted to antiphlogistic theories. Joseph Priestley first prepared oxygen, 1774.

August 2

Albert Einstein sent letter about military implications of atomic energy to President Franklin Roosevelt, 1939. Leopold Gmelin born 1788: Gmelin's salt (potassium ferricyanide); test for bile pigments; History of science and chemistry [auf Deutsch]; Handbuch der anorganischen Chemie and its successor database. The 1843 edition of the handbook contains remarkable V-shaped table of elements. Benjamin Rush, professor of chemistry at College of Philadelphia, signed US Declaration of Independence, 1776. Friedrich Stromeyer born 1776: discoverer of cadmium (Cd, element 48); analysis of minerals.

August 3

John Wilfred Linnett born 1913: molecular structure; combustion and flame kinetics. Koichi Tanaka born 1959: mass spectrometric analysis of biological macromolecules; Nobel prize 2002. George Whitesides born 1939: use of enzymes in organic synthesis; combination of chemistry, biology, biochemistry and material science. Alexander Williamson reads paper on synthesis of ethers to British Association, 1850.

August 4

Jeanette Grasselli Brown born 1928: vibrational spectroscopy; edited Atlas of Spectral Data and Physical Constants for Organic Compounds; Garvan Medal, 1985 Robert Williams and Robert Waterman are awarded US patent 2,049,988 for a process for obtaining vitamins, 1936.

August 5

Seymour Richard Lipsky born 1924: electron capture detector; high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC). Thomas Burr Osborne born 1859: proteins and their amino acid content; Vitamin A and cod-liver oil. Standard Oil of New Jersey incorporated, 1882. Standard Oil was broken up in an antitrust action.

August 6

Alexander Fleming born 1881: discoverer of penicillin; Nobel prize (Medicine), 1945. William Hyde Wollaston born 1766: discoverer of palladium (Pd, element 46) and rhodium (Rh, 45); equivalent weights. (View his paper on acid salts.)

August 7

Germain Henri Hess born 1802 (or possibly August 8): thermochemistry; Hess's law in his terms and in modern terms (John) Paul Hogan born 1919: polyolefin plastics, including polypropylene and high-density polyethylene (HDPE). Arthur Michael born 1853: entropy-based theory of organic reactions; Michael addition reaction George Pimentel announced evidence of methane and ammonia detected near Mars by Mariner 7 spacecraft, 1969.

August 8

Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac born 1902: relativistic quantum mechanics, including electron spin (Dirac equation); Nobel Prize (physics), 1933. Ernest Orlando Lawrence born 1901: nuclear chemist; built the first cyclotron; Nobel prize (Physics), 1939. Element 103 lawrencium, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory were named in his honor. Benjamin Silliman born 1779: professor of chemistry at Yale; founder and editor of American Journal of Science.

August 9

Amedeo Avogadro born 1776: hypothesized that equal volumes of gas contain equal numbers of molecules and that common gaseous elements were (in modern terminology) diatomic; Avogadro constant named after him (by Jean Perrin, 1909) William Alfred Fowler born 1911: nuclear synthesis of chemical elements in stars; Nobel prize (Physics), 1983. Erich Hückel born 1896: colligative properties; electrolyte activity (Debye-Hückel theory); molecular orbital methods (Hückel theory); Hückel rule for aromaticity. Patent for production of taxol, an important cancer drug, issued to Robert Holton, 1994. William Thomas Green Morton born 1819: demonstrated ether as an anesthetic at Massachusetts General Hospital. Aleksandr Vasil'evich Topchiev born 1907: Soviet petrochemical industry.

August 10

Louis Brus born 1943: quantum dots; Nobel prize, 2023. Chester Garfield Fisher born 1881: Fisher Scientific Felix Hoffmann of Bayer made a stable derivative of salicylic acid in 1897. This pain-reliever had fewer side effects than the parent acid, and is now known as aspirin. Henry Moseley, who discovered atomic number, was killed at Gallipoli in World War I, 1915. Arne Tiselius born 1902: biochemist; electrophoresis; Nobel prize, 1948.

August 11

Bristol-Myers (now Bristol-Myers Squibb) incorporated 1933.

Erwin Chargaff born 1905: base-pairing in DNA Harold Baily Dixon born 1852: combustion and explosions of gases Christiaan Eijkman born 1858: discovered Vitamin B1 (thiamine) and its role in beriberi; Nobel Prize (medicine), 1929. Cato Maximilian Guldberg born 1836: formulated law of mass action (with brother-in-law Peter Waage) Aaron Klug born 1926: investigation of nucleic-acid protein complexes with crystallographic electron microscopy; Nobel prize, 1982

August 12

Margaret Burbidge born Eleanor Margaret Peachey 1919: stellar nucleosynthesis of chemical elements; president of AAAS; director of Royal Observatory (Greenwich, UK) Joseph Lister first uses antiseptic chemicals in surgery, 1865. Read part of his report. James Muspratt born 1793: manufacture of acids; father of James Sheridan Muspratt (author of Chemistry, Theoretical, Practical and Analytical as applied and relating to the Arts and Manufactures). Erwin Schrödinger born 1887: quantum mechanics (wave mechanics); Schrödinger equation; Nobel prize (Physics), 1933

August 13

Anders Jonas Ångström born 1814: emission and absorption spectra of chemical elements; angstrom unit = 10-10 m. Salvador Luria born 1912: microbial genetics; Nobel prize (Medicine), 1969 Julian Friedrich Miescher born 1844: discovered nucleic acids. John William Strutt (Lord Rayleigh) and William Ramsay made preliminary announcement of the discovery of argon (Ar, element 18) at BAAS meeting, 1894. Frederick Sanger born 1918: structure of proteins including insulin; base-pair sequences of nucleic acids; Nobel prize, 1958 and 1980. George Gabriel Stokes born 1819: mathematical physicist; fluorescence (Stokes shift is named for him); spectroscopy; fluid dynamics (Navier-Stokes equations) Richard Martin Willstätter born 1872: aliphatic amines and alkaloids; Nobel prize, 1915

August 14

Paul Doughty Bartlett born 1907: kinetics and mechanisms of organic reactions Richard Robert Ernst: high-resolution NMR spectroscopy, particularly Fourier-transform and two-dimensional methods; Nobel prize, 1991. May Sybil Leslie born 1887: decay of thorium and characterization of isotopes of radon (known then as emanations of thorium and actinium) Hans Christian Ørsted born 1777: first to isolate aluminum (Al, element 13); electricity and magnetism (Ørsted effect)

August 15

Louis de Broglie born 1892: wave-particle duality (de Broglie relation); Nobel Prize (physics), 1929. Gerty Theresa Cori (née Radnitz) born 1896: carbohydrate metabolism; discovered how glycogen is catalytically converted; Nobel prize (Medicine) (with husband, Carl), 1947. Richard Heck born 1931: palladium-catalyzed cross couplings in organic synthesis; Nobel prize, 2010. William Augustus Tilden born 1842: specific heats of elements; organic bases and alkaloids. Read his Famous Chemists.

August 16

Frederic Stanley Kipping born 1863: optical activity, organosilicon compounds, particularly silicones. Johan Kjeldahl born 1849: analytical method for nitrogen; Kjeldahl flask. Anne L'Huillier born 1958; electron dynamics via attosecond pulses of electromagnetic radiation, Nobel Prize (Physics), 2023. Wendell Meredith Stanley born 1904: chemical nature of viruses; crystallized tobacco mosaic virus; Nobel prize, 1946

August 17

Aldrich Chemical (now part of Millipore Sigma) established 1951

Walter Noddack born 1893: co-discoverer of rhenium (Re, element 75) with wife Ida and Otto Berg John Francis Queeny born 1859: founded Monsanto, one of the world's most controversial agribusinesses, now a part of Bayer

Principal Sources: Milestones in Chemistry Calendar, Copyright © 1996, remains the principal source of information; however, I have checked (and in some cases corrected) its birth dates. Chemical and Engineering News "Top 75" (75th anniversary issue, 1/12/98) and Biographical Encyclopedia of Scientists edited by John Daintith et al. (Institute of Physics, 2nd ed, 1994) are other important sources. Women in Chemistry and Physics : a Biobibliographic Sourcebook, edited by Louise S. Grinstein, Rose K. Rose, and Miriam H. Rafailovich and Notable Women in the Physical Sciences edited by Benjamin F. and Barbara S. Shearer have helped me to add several women to the calendar. The Illustrated Almanac of Science, Technology, and Invention by Raymond L. Francis is the source of several entries. Thanks to all interested readers who have suggested events for inclusion; Lucio Gelmini has been particularly helpful in this regard.

Dates are given according to the Gregorian calendar to the extent I could find them. (Note: this applies particularly to 19th-century Russians.)
